facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 331 of 1961 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 331 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal is by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 20, 1961 of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ No. 460 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 20, 1961, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ No. 460 of 1961.

facts.text: Appellant claims to be the trustee of a Public Trust created for the management of certain properties situated in Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claims to be the trustee of a Public Trust created for the management of certain properties situated in Amritsar.

facts.text: One of the trust properties is a dharamshala.

anchor.surface_text: Of the properties belonging to the trust is one which is said to be a dharamshala.

facts.text: Amritsar Improvement Trust passed a resolution dated March 21, 1957 to acquire a portion of the property for widening a road under a development scheme framed under s. 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: By a resolution of the Amritsar Improvement Trust dated March 21, 1957 the Improvement Trust decided to acquire a portion of this property for the purpose of widening a road under a development-scheme

facts.text: It is common ground that a scheme has been framed under s. 3, finalised after considering objections.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that a scheme has been framed under s. 3 and this has been finalised after considering objections.

facts.text: Improvement Trust took steps to acquire property bearing Municipal No. 2320/1, 884/9 belonging to the appellant-trust pursuant to the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: It was in pursuance of this scheme that the Improvement Trust took steps to effect the acquisition of the property bearing Municipal No. 2320/1, 884/9 belonging to the appel- lant-trust.

facts.text: Appellant filed a suit for declaration that acquisition proceedings were illegal and for permanent injunction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a suit for a declaration that the acquisition proceedings were illegal and ultra vires and for a permanent injunction restraining the Improvement Trust

facts.text: The suit was withdrawn by reason of a Consent Memo.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was, however, withdrawn by reason of a Consent Memo which was filed

facts.text: Appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court challenging validity of Improvement Trust action.

anchor.surface_text: subsequently the appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Punjab High Court challenging the validity of the action of the Improvement Trust

facts.text: The writ petition was summarily dismissed by Punjab High Court on April 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The petition, however, was summarily dismissed by the High Court by order dated April 20, 1961.

facts.text: Appellant's petition for certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) was dismissed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The further petition filed by the appellant praying for a certificate of fitness under Art. 133 1  c  was also dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal against High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the appellant obtained special leave of this Court to prefer an appeal against the judgment of the High Court

facts.text: Notification issued in April 1948 under s.3 of Punjab Damaged Areas Act, 1947 declaring the area as damaged.

anchor.surface_text: it was in Pursuance of this provision that the numberification of April 1948, to which we have referred, was issued.

facts.text: Punjab Damaged Areas Act, 1947 (Punj. Act 11 of 1947) was enacted by Governor under s.93 of Government of India Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: By a proclamation issued under s. 93 of the Government of India Act, 1935 the Governor of the Punjab assumed to- himself the powers vested in the Punjab Provincial Legislature and under the powers so vested he enacted the Punjab Damaged Areas Act, 1947  Punj. Act 11 of 1947 .

facts.text: Governor's rule under s.93 ended on August 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The rule of the Governor under s.93 ended on August 15, 1947

facts.text: 1947 Act continued till August 15, 1949 and no further.

anchor.surface_text: The result was that the Punjab Act of 1947 continued till August 15,1949 and no further.

facts.text: East Punjab Damaged Areas Act, 1949 was enacted to fill the gap after expiry of 1947 Act.

anchor.surface_text: It was to make provision for the gap that would be caused by the expiry of this Act in 1949 that the East Punjab Damaged Areas Act, 1949, which is referred to in s.2 d  of the Act of 1951, was enacted.

facts.text: s.3 of 1949 Act brought into force in April 1949.

anchor.surface_text: s.3 which enabled the State Government by numberification to declare an urban area to be a  damaged area was brought into force at once, i.e., in April 1949

facts.text: No notification under s.1(3) of 1949 Act bringing ss.4 to 21 into force before August 15, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of diligent research numbernotification under s. 1 3  bringing the rest of the Act into force companyld be discovered in any event, there is numberhing to show that the rest of the sections were brought into force before August 15, 1949

facts.text: No notification under 1949 Act declared the area as damaged area.

anchor.surface_text: the only other areas contemplated are those which were numberified under the Act of 1949 which on any numbermal and reasonable companystruction companyld only include the areas which were the subject of numberification under s. 3 of the Act of 1949 and number those under the Act of 1947

facts.text: Respondents contended that 1947 notification deemed issued under 1949 Act by virtue of s.22 Punjab General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: Based on the fact that the Act of 1949 practically reproduces, the earlier Act of 1947 the companytention urged before us was that the Act of 1947 was in effect repealed and re-enacted by the Act of 1949, that by virtue of s. 22 of the Punjab General Clauses Act...

facts.text: Court held there was no repeal of 1947 Act, express or implied, so s.22 does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument. In the first place, there was numberrepeal of the Act of 1947 to attract the application of the rule of companystruction embodied in S. 22 of the Punjab General Clauses Act.

facts.text: The area is not a damaged area under s.2(d) of 1951 Act.

anchor.surface_text: in this view we consider that the appellant is entitled to the relief sought because the acquisition was in respect of a scheme for an area which it was number within the power of the Improvement Trust to frame under s. 3 of the Act.

facts.text: Proceedings for acquisition of appellant's property under 1951 Act are quashed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal succeeds and there will be a direction that the proceedings for the acquisition of the property belonging to the appellant under the Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act, 1951 be quashed.
subsequently the appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Punjab High Court challenging the validity of the action of the Improvement Trust
The further petition filed by the appellant praying for a certificate of fitness under Art. 133 1  c  was also dismissed.

arguments.court_reasoning: On proper construction of s.2(d), only notifications under 1949 or 1951 Acts qualify; 1947 does not.

arguments.claim: The 1947 Act was repealed and re-enacted by the 1949 Act, so by virtue of s.22 Punjab General Clauses Act, the 1947 notification is deemed issued under the 1949 Act.

holdings.text: There was no repeal of the Act of 1947 to attract the application of the rule of construction embodied in s. 22 of the Punjab General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument. In the first place, there was no repeal of the Act of 1947 to attract the application of the rule of construction embodied in S. 22 of the Punjab General Clauses Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express repeal; conceded that temporary enactments could be repealed but not here; s.22 requires repeal which is absent.

holdings.text: There is no basis for invoking the doctrine of implied repeal as there is no inconsistency between the two enactments; implied repeals are not favoured where statutes are identical and run parallel.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the respondents submitted that by reason of the very existence of the enactments of 1947 and 1949 on the Statute Book in terms identical with each other, the earlier statute should be held to have been impliedly repealed by the later enactment. If, as we have pointed out earlier, the first Act was temporary and Its place was taken by a later enactment after the former ceased to be in force, it is obvious that there could be no scope for invoking the principal embodied in s. 22 of the Punjab Central Clauses Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Temporary 1947 Act lapsed; identical permanent 1949 Act; no inconsistency allowing implied repeal; maxim against implied repeals.

holdings.text: The only other areas contemplated by s.2(d) are those notified under the Act of 1949 which on any normal and reasonable construction could only include areas notified under s.3 of the Act of 1949 and not those under the Act of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: the only other areas contemplated are those which were notified under the Act of 1949 which on any normal and reasonable construction could only include the areas which were the subject of notification under s. 3 of the Act of 1949 and not those under the Act of 1947

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proper interpretation of s.2(d) of 1951 Act; 'notified under the Act of 1949' refers specifically to notifications under that Act's s.3.

holdings.text: The area is not a damaged area under s.2(d) of the 1951 Act; the appellant is entitled to relief as the scheme was not within the power of the Improvement Trust under s.3.

anchor.surface_text: in this view we consider that the appellant is entitled to the relief sought because the acquisition was in respect of a scheme for an area which it was not within the power of the Improvement Trust to frame under s. 3 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.2(d) construction to facts; 1948 notification under 1947 Act does not qualify.

holdings.text: The appellant was not precluded from challenging the scheme by s.5(4); conclusive effect applies only to formalities under ss.3-5, not jurisdictional fact of damaged area.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that there is no substance in this argument. The foundation of the jurisdiction of the Improvement Trust to frame a scheme... depends upon the scheme relating to a damaged area and if... the property now sought to be acquired is within an area which does not fall within the definition of a damaged area

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5(4) conclusive only on procedural formalities; total lack of jurisdiction where prerequisite 'damaged area' absent cannot be cured.

holdings.text: The Punjab Act of 1947 continued till August 15, 1949 and no further.

anchor.surface_text: The result was that the Punjab Act of 1947 continued till August 15,1949 and no further.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpretation of s.93(4) Government of India Act 1935 and continuance provisions post-independence.

holdings.text: The appeal succeeds and the proceedings for the acquisition of the property under the Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act, 1951 be quashed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal succeeds and there will be a direction that the proceedings for the acquisition of the property belonging to the appellant under the Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act, 1951 be quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequence of holdings on issues; acquisition ultra vires due to lack of jurisdiction.
